questions.text: Endopeptidases are a group of hydrolases that catalyze the hydrolysis of peptidic bonds, and thus, hydrolyze proteins. These enzymes are also very chemo-, regio- and enantioselective, which are active under soft reaction conditions (pH 6–8) and are easily handled biocatalysts that do not require the presence of cofactors. They break peptide bonds of nonterminal amino acids (i.e. within the molecule). For this reason, endopeptidases cannot break down peptides into monomers. They are usually very specific for certain amino acids. All are endopeptidases EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Pancreatic proteases are of two types:
(1)Endopeptidases– They hydrolyze interior peptide bonds of polypeptides and proteins.Trypsin, chymotrypsin, and elastaseare endopeptidases.
(2)Exopeptidases– They hydrolyze external peptide bonds of polypeptides and proteins.Carboxypeptidases A & Bare exopeptidases.

questions.text: A 55 years old male accident victim in casualty urgently needs blood. The blood bank is unable to determine his ABO group, as his red cell group and plasma group does not match. Emergency transfusion of the patient should be with:

options.label: A
options.text: RBC corresponding to his red cell group and colloids/ crystalloid

options.label: B
options.text: Whole blood corresponding to his plasma group

questions.correct_answer: C. O positive RBC and colloids/crystalloid
questions.explanation:
1. If the patient’s blood group is known, an unmatched blood group of the same group may be used.
  2. If the patient’s blood cannot be determined, Group O red blood cells should be chosen. The use of such unmatched blood should be Rh (–ve) when used in women of child-bearing age in whom we do not want sensitization to Rh antigen.
  3. As Rh-negative blood is often in limited supply, Rh-positive blood is used in the emergency transfusion of older females and males of unknown blood groups. In such cases, sensitization may occur but the risk of an immediate hemolytic reaction is low. O blood group is the universal donor and therefore, should be given to this patient.

questions.text: A 56yrs old, female patient presented with complaints of gradually increasing dyspnea on exertion over the past 2yrs. On examination, she has an apical diastolic murmur. On further work up with echocardiography, Hockey-stick appearance is seen. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
HOCKEY STICK SIGNS
ECG

Digoxin effect
Echocardiography

Mitral stenosis.

  • Normal, biphasic, and rapid motion of the mitral valve is altered because it opens only partly and as a single unit.
  • The posterior leaflet becomes immobile and the anterior mitral leaflet tethering results in a "hockey stick" appearance.
  • These changes obstructs the blood flow from the atrium to the ventricle
MRI Brain
  • Hockey-stick sign of v CJD
  • FLAIR image shows symmetrical pulvinar and dorsomedial thalamic nuclear hyperintensity.
  • This combination gives a characteristic "hockey-stick" appearance.

Organ preservation is the supply line for organ transplantation. options.text: Oxygen is more soluble in cold solutions and provides a continual supply for energy metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: There is no way to suppress microbial growth except by cooling and slowing the growth rate

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothermia diminishes energy requirements and allows the limited energy reserve to keep the organ alive

options.label: D
options.text: It slows metabolism and the enzymic processes that would destroy the cell

A 75-year-old man is brought to the casualty with sudden syncopal episode while playing with his grandchildren.
